title: Johnson & Johnson Places Talc Injury Claims in Bankruptcy; Healthcare company places into chapter 11 a corporate affiliate holding talc-related injury liabilities, confirming fears of plaintiffs' lawyers
text:
The bankruptcy filing confirms the fears of injury lawyers, who had voiced worries that J&J would put talc claims into chapter 11 to stop jury verdicts, protect assets and pressure plaintiffs to accept settlements.

"We are taking these actions to bring certainty to all parties involved in the cosmetic talc cases," said Michael Ullmann, J&J's executive vice president and general counsel.

As of July, the company faced roughly 34,600 lawsuits linking its talc-based baby powder to ovarian cancer, asbestos cancer and other illnesses. J&J has said its talcum powder, which it stopped selling last year, is safe and doesn't cause cancer, and that numerous tests over the past 40 years didn't show a presence of asbestos.

J&J, which hasn't filed for bankruptcy, said Thursday that it is providing financial backing for a settlement with injury victims.
